docs.snippet: The new government, elected on a pledge to revive a stalled peace effort with ethnic Tamil rebels, has matched a monthlong cease-fire declared by the rebels to begin Dec. 24. Last month the rebels said for the first time that they would settle for...
docs.lead_paragraph: The new government, elected on a pledge to revive a stalled peace effort with ethnic Tamil rebels, has matched a monthlong cease-fire declared by the rebels to begin Dec. 24. Last month the rebels said for the first time that they would settle for less than a separate nation for the minority Tamils. The government and rebels have been fighting for 18 years in a civil war that has killed more than 62,000 people in the island nation of 19 million people. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
docs.abstract: Sri Lanka's new government, elected on pledge to revive stalled peace effort with ethnic Tamil rebels, matches monthlong cease-fire declared by rebels to begin Dec 24 (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Cease-Fire, On Both Sides

docs.snippet: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in Crawford, Tex., by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain as recorded by The New York Times. The full transcript is available at nytimes.com/world.    Mr. Bush      The pr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in Crawford, Tex., by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain as recorded by The New York Times. The full transcript is available at nytimes.com/world. Mr. Bush The prime minister and I both understand that defeating global terror requires a broad-based, long-term strategy. We understand the importance of denying terrorists weapons of mass destruction. And we understand the importance of adapting NATO to meet new threats even as NATO prepares to take on new members and forges a new relationship with Russia.
docs.abstract: Excerpts from news conference held by Pres Bush and Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain in Crawford, Tex; photos (M)

headline.main: Allies Discuss Terrorism and the Middle East: Bush and Blair on Policy

docs.snippet: King Gyanendra has issued a directive relaxing a state of emergency that has restricted political parties and the news media since November. Under the new guidelines political groups can hold meetings and rallies after obtaining approval and journ...
docs.lead_paragraph: King Gyanendra has issued a directive relaxing a state of emergency that has restricted political parties and the news media since November. Under the new guidelines political groups can hold meetings and rallies after obtaining approval and journalists can use nongovernment news sources in their reports about Nepal's Maoist insurrection. The rebels have been fighting to overthrow the constitutional monarchy since 1996. Barry Bearak (NYT)
docs.abstract: Nepal King Gyanendra eases state of emeergency that restricted political parties and news media since Nov; will let journalists use nongovernment news sources in reports about Maoist rebels (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: State Of Emergency Eased

docs.snippet: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about women who were soldiers in the Civil War misstated the number of dead in the battle of Antietam. It was at least 3,650; the casualty figure of more than 22,000 included wounded, missing and captured....
docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about women who were soldiers in the Civil War misstated the number of dead in the battle of Antietam. It was at least 3,650; the casualty figure of more than 22,000 included wounded, missing and captured.
docs.abstract: Correction of March 23 article in Arts & Ideas section on women who were soldiers in US Civil War

docs.snippet: An independent historians' commission, wrapping up five years of research into Switzerland's wartime past, concluded today that the country's neutrality was twisted to justify policies that helped the Nazis, including turning away Jews fleeing the...
docs.lead_paragraph: An independent historians' commission, wrapping up five years of research into Switzerland's wartime past, concluded today that the country's neutrality was twisted to justify policies that helped the Nazis, including turning away Jews fleeing the Holocaust. In its final report, the nine-member panel found that the Swiss authorities in World War II knew that turning back the refugees meant likely death. The authorities cooperated unduly with the Nazis and failed to return assets to their rightful owners when the war ended, the panel concluded.
docs.abstract: Independent historians' commission, wrapping up five years of research into Switzerland's wartime past, concludes that country's neutrality was twisted to justify policies that helped Nazis; finds that Swiss authorities in World War II knew that turning back Jewish refugees meant likely death; concludes that authorities cooperated unduly with Nazis and failed to return assets to their rightful owners when war ended (M)

headline.main: Commission Concludes That Swiss Policies Aided the Nazis

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES

docs.snippet: Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba traveled to India and will discuss Nepal's increasingly violent Maoist rebellion. The Indian government has been supportive of Nepal's effort to put down the insurgency and Mr. Deuba is expected to make further pl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba traveled to India and will discuss Nepal's increasingly violent Maoist rebellion. The Indian government has been supportive of Nepal's effort to put down the insurgency and Mr. Deuba is expected to make further pleas for help in shutting down various supply routes to the guerrillas. Nepal has been under a state of emergency since November, when the Maoists abandoned a truce. Barry Bearak (NYT)
docs.abstract: Nepal's Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba travels to India to make plea for help in putting down Maoist insurgency (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Seeking Help With Rebellion

docs.snippet: The Bush administration plans to ask Congress to lift restrictions on American military aid to Colombia in order to help the government in Bogotá fight leftist rebels, officials said today.    If approved by lawmakers, the change would open a new...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration plans to ask Congress to lift restrictions on American military aid to Colombia in order to help the government in Bogotá fight leftist rebels, officials said today. If approved by lawmakers, the change would open a new front in Colombia for American military trainers and equipment by involving the United States directly in the fight against the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.
docs.abstract: Bush administration plans to ask Congress to lift restrictions on American military aid to Colombia to help government there fight leftist rebels; until now Congress has restricted use of aid to struggle against narcotics traffickers (S)

headline.main: Administration Seeks Unlimited Military Aid for Colombia

docs.snippet: The police station near the top of the steep hill looked ready for battle, as soldiers in camouflage carrying assault rifles stood guard behind sandbags. Yet everywhere else in the San Francisco neighborhood, people strolled calmly while children ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The police station near the top of the steep hill looked ready for battle, as soldiers in camouflage carrying assault rifles stood guard behind sandbags. Yet everywhere else in the San Francisco neighborhood, people strolled calmly while children played in the dusty streets. After years of gang fights, kidnappings, robberies and assaults, the Honduran government finally declared a nationwide ''war against crime'' in late January. Now thousands of soldiers and police officers patrol violent neighborhoods and crowded commercial strips.
docs.abstract: Honduran government launches zero-tolerance campaign against lawlessness, especially in capital of Tegucigalpa; alarming increase in common crime has followed peace accords that ended decades of military rule and civil war; Pres Ricardo Maduro, who lost son in botched 1977 kidnapping, drew inspiration for anticrime strategy from visit to New York City in 2001; met with police officials to learn about zero-tolerance approach, in which small crimes were pursued as vigorously as big ones; photo; map (M)

headline.main: Tegucigalpa Journal; On Mean Streets, a U.S. Import: Zero Tolerance

docs.snippet: Anyone made jumpy by the sharp bursts of automatic rifle fire would be well advised not to come here. There is no war, but this is a one-industry town: guns.     Small boys fill cartridges to make bullets; their brothers operate drill presses; the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone made jumpy by the sharp bursts of automatic rifle fire would be well advised not to come here. There is no war, but this is a one-industry town: guns. Small boys fill cartridges to make bullets; their brothers operate drill presses; their fathers file away on stocks.
docs.abstract: Over 3,000 father-and-son operations that make, trade and sell weapons from open-front shops line streets of isolated Darra Adam Khel, Pakistan; gunsmithing tradition goes back at least century, passed down through generations; customers include rebel armies from around world and Pakistanis; map; photo (M)

headline.main: Darra Adam Khel Journal; When It's Business, the City Sticks to Its Guns

docs.snippet: Protestants in north Belfast clashed with the police on Wednesday night and yesterday afternoon, hurling homemade explosives that wounded 13 officers in the city's worst rioting since last autumn. At least five gunshots were fired toward Catholic ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Protestants in north Belfast clashed with the police on Wednesday night and yesterday afternoon, hurling homemade explosives that wounded 13 officers in the city's worst rioting since last autumn. At least five gunshots were fired toward Catholic homes in the Ardoyne neighborhood and the police responded with plastic bullets. The police said the violence had been orchestrated by the Ulster Defense Association, an illegal paramilitary group. Brian Lavery (NYT)
docs.abstract: Protestants clash with police, north Belfast, Northern Ireland, in violence police charge is orchestrated by Ulster Defense Association, illegal paramilitary group; hurl homemade explosives that wound 13 officers (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Protestants Fight Police
